Award.AwardTitle: LTREB renewal: Climatic change and community organization across three trophic levels: long-term research at a sentinel site in semiarid north-central Chile
Award.AbstractNarration:
Increases in semi-arid and arid lands may affect economic stability and societies globally. This long-term project examines the shifting forces that influence a semi-arid community and thus serves as an important sentinel for societal ramifications of increased aridity with climate change. Since 1989, unexpected changes in rainfall patterns and species invasions have replaced native species interactions as key drivers of a semi-arid thorn scrub community in northern Chile. Long-term ecological data from this site contribute directly to decisions on wise management of these changing environments. It also will provide information to help the general public understand the decision-making process by improving their knowledge of its wildlife and natural areas. The project will provide important comparisons with ongoing research in semi-arid sites in North America, where important drivers of long-term change differ. The project represents a long-term collaboration between US and Chilean researchers and managers, and will provide valuable opportunities for US students to participate in international research.

This long-term field project utilizes 20 experimental grids in which small mammals and ephemeral plants are sampled monthly, cover by shrubs is measured every three months, soil samples are taken every 4 months to estimate seed density, and fox owl diets are assessed. Previous results document the effects of predators on small mammals and plants that were overwhelmed by El Ni침o‐associated rainfall. Based on predictions of more frequent and intense El Ni침o events as a consequence of ongoing global climate change, the project will emphasize the dual and interactive roles of climate change and invasive species (lagomorphs, numerous ephemeral plants) on community-level dynamics in this habitat. Data collected over the next five years will be analyzed to answer three important questions: 1) will a major El Ni침o event in the next 5 years reverse the trends that have been apparent since 2002, or has a critical transition occurred that will be stable for the foreseeable future? 2) what further changes may ensue from the apparent decline in perennial shrub cover and an increase in invasive vegetation since 2003? and 3) what will be the consequences of these changes for the north-central Chilean semiarid zone more generally? These goals are facilitated by extensive collaboration with multiple investigators in Chile, Spain, and the United States. This research integrates population, community, and geographical ecology in the context of global climate change and predicted vegetative responses, spans 3 trophic levels, and provides important insight into the relative importance of biotic vs. abiotic factors, and top-down versus bottom-up control in semi-arid systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our long-term research in north-central Chile has now completed its 31st year of field effort. Initially designed to evaluate the relative importance of competition vs. predation in this semi-arid system, the importance of abiotic, extrinsic influences became evident when rainfall associated with the El Niño Southern Oscillation (ENSO) exceeded 200 mm in both 1991 and 1992 (the long-term mean is about 125 mm), and the project shifted to focus on the relative importance of biotic (predation, competition) and abiotic (rainfall) factors. By about 2003 we had experienced three El Niño/wet periods, and the responses by plants, small mammals, and predators were qualitatively similar. Plant productivity increased dramatically, feeding an increase in small mammal numbers, which resulted in greater food for predators; however, the dry phase of the ENSO cycle returned within 1-3 years, with resulting reduction in plant and small mammal abundance. We initiated inventories of birds and insects around this time in order to compare their responses to those of small mammals to rainy/dry periods.

However, since about 2000-2002 our site (and north-central Chile more generally) appears to have experienced a major change in rainfall patterns, with greatly reduced mean annual rainfall coupled with significantly reduced variation across years; from 1989 through 2002 we saw three wet periods, and mean annual rainfall was 149 mm (SD = 120 mm), whereas from 2003 through 2020 we have seen only one similarly wet year (in 2017), and annual rainfall declined to 109 mm (SD 71 mm). Chile is now considered to be in a “mega-drought”; 13 of the past 18 years have been well below the recent mean, four have modestly exceeded the mean, and one year (2017) proved to be the second wettest year in our 31-year record. The long-term consequences of such drought remains to be seen.

One apparent consequence of the altered rainfall regime has been elevated dominance of one small mammal species, the degu (Octodon degus), which has comprised at least 50% of the biomass of small mammals at our site in all but two 6-month periods since 2001 (and ≥60% in all but six). The cyclical relative abundances observed during “typical” ENSO cycles in the first decade of this study have given way to greatly dampened cycles characterized by much higher proportions of degus, and may reflect a fundamental assemblage shift at this site. Degus are diurnal and an important food source for many predators at this site. They also are herbivorous and they indirectly facilitate the establishment of non-native annual plant species by reducing cover by native plant species.

Given these observations, research over the past five years emphasized monitoring of diverse elements that comprised the initial research emphasis (ephemeral plants, shrubs, small mammals, predators) as well as groups that have since come to our attention as potentially important here. Introduced lagomorphs (European rabbit, European hare) also facilitate invasion of exotic plants and appear to have sporadic population fluctuations in response to rainfall. Bird community structure and composition fluctuates seasonally and we continued to monitor this in preparation for wetter times; a key crew member has left our project, however, so bird surveys may need to be terminated. Insects are now monitored as key food for birds as well as one core small mammal species, the marsupial mouse (Thylamys elegans).

The COVID-19 pandemic impacted our field efforts since early 2020. Our field site is in a National Park, and the Chilean park service closed all parks in April 2020. Our field crew was not allowed back until October, at which they were given limited access. We resumed small mammal monitoring in December. Coquimbo Province has been one of the “hot spots” in Chile with respect to COVID-19 infections. As such, we remain uncertain of ongoing access; for now, however, monthly efforts are underway again.

Population estimates for small mammals appear somewhat unexpected in that numbers of two “core” species (Phyllotis darwini, Abrothrix olivacea) appear to have increased since the pandemic lockdown, but the other “core” taxon, Octodon degus, has declined. We believe this may reflect differential trappability, as the former two species have exhibited >90% monthly trappability, whereas our records suggest that around 65% of the degus in this population are captured monthly. If this is the case, and assuming some level of population turnover during the 8 months when we were unable to sample, we would expect that fully sampling the Octodon population would take longer than for Phyllotis or Abrothrix. Related to this, the demographic metric is minimum number known alive (MNKA), and following eight months of mortality but no opportunity to mark new recruits, MNKA might be expected to underestimate populations that exhibit low trappability.
